An investment chief who oversees $29 billion explains why he's bullish on a niche industry that's 'like the red blood cell of tech' — and shares 2 stocks he's buying ... Over the years, high barriers to entry have kept the semiconductor capital industry small. "There's a complete lack of competition in some sense in most of the assembly lines for a semiconductor," Chung said. Including his two stock picks, he counts only five companies that dominate the space and provide supply chipmakers with the equipment they need to make everyday devices. Other players include KLA-Tencor, ASML, and Tokyo Electron. "There's no piece of software that doesn't run on a piece of hardware, and there's no hardware that doesn't have a lot of semiconductors in it," Chung said.
